title-group.article-title: Determination of Gurson–Tvergaard–Needleman Model Parameters for Failure of a Polymeric Material

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Bogazici University, Bebek, Istanbul 34342, Turkey
Department of Mechanical Engineering, Bogazici University, Bebek, Istanbul 34342, Turkey
Department of Aerospace Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, 104 South Wright Street, Urbana, IL 61801, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. E-mail: oralalpa@boun.edu.tr

abstract.p: In this work, the Gurson–Tvergaard–Needleman model, commonly used for metallic materials, is applied to the failure of a polymeric material – specifically a polyethylene carbon monoxide copolymer, which is an enhanced photodegradable material. Gurson–Tvergaard–Needleman model parameters for this material are obtained using the Nelder–Mead simplex method when correlating experimental and numerical results of both tensile and fracture specimens. Results show that the Gurson–Tvergaard–Needleman model can also be used for polymeric materials with selection of proper parameters that are quite different from the ones proposed for metallic materials.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: A well-known ductile damage continuum model is the Gurson– Tvergaard–Needleman (GTN) model (Gurson, 1977; Tvergaard, 1981; Tvergaard and Needleman, 1984), which is based on the concept of void nucleation, growth, and coalescence as being the mechanism responsible for damage and failure in ductile metals. Physically motivated by void-induced failure process, the GTN model has been widely used to predict load–deformation and fracture resistance behavior of a range of ductile metallic materials such as steel, cast iron, copper, and aluminum (see, e.g., Sun et al., 1989; Narasimhan et al., 1992; Brocks et al., 1996; Kuna and Sun, 1996; Skallerud and Zhang, 1997; Xia and Cheng, 1997; Faleskog et al., 1998; Pardoen et al., 1998; Steglich and Brocks, 1998; Gullerud et al., 2000; Shirizly et al., 2007; Al-Abbasi and Nemes, 2008; Benseddiq and Imad, 2008).

Numerical implementation of the GTN model to polymers is limited primarily because the void nucleation, growth, and coalescence process is not present in most polymers in the same way it is in metals. However, the GTN model is a continuum softening and failure model, so an appropriate selection of parameters could make the model applicable to failure of polymers. For example, Jeong (2002) modified the Gurson yield function by combining it with Coulomb’s yield function, and calculated cavitation and plastic zone sizes for a rubber-modified epoxy specimen under symmetric double-edge double-notched four-point bending. Fracture toughness of steel compact tension (CT) specimens bonded with rubber-modified epoxy and bulk rubber-modified epoxy single-edge-notched bending (SENB) specimens were investigated numerically using GTN model by Imanaka et al. (2003). Numerical and experimental relations between J-integral values and crack extension were compared there for both the CT and SENB specimens. Using the GTN model for damage accumulation, Zaïri et al. (2005, 2008a) studied both experimentally and numerically the uniaxial tensile and volumetric strain response of a rubber-toughened polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) and high-impact polystyrene for different strain rates at room temperature. Zaïri et al. (2008b) also studied equal channel angular extrusion and uniaxial tensile tests for polypropylene specimens. In Challier et al. (2006) and Laiarinandrasana et al. (2009), the effects of strain rate and temperature on mechanical properties (elastic, plastic, viscous, and GTN model parameters) were investigated for polyvinylidene fluoride by comparing experimental and numerical stress–strain responses for smooth, circumferentially notched round specimens, and load-crack opening displacement responses for SENB specimens. The mechanical behavior of porous polymers with different volume fraction of voids under different macroscopic stress triaxiality was investigated numerically by Riku et al. (2010) using a unit cell computation, and theoretical results based on a modified Gurson model. Their results showed little dependence on the arrangement of voids.

Although generally good agreements have been reported between numerical and experimental results in the above-mentioned studies of polymers, there is no specific framework on how GTN model parameters can be consistently determined from experiments on polymeric materials, or how a link between tensile and fracture response can be made. Typically, either tensile response or fracture response was investigated independently, and no attempts were made to connect the two in a common minimization framework. Making such a connection in the context of a robust optimization framework is one of the goals of the present study. Plastic yielding of polymers is generally characterized not only with the equivalent von Mises stress but also with the hydrostatic stress. A pressure-dependent yield criterion can be assumed for this behavior. Three such criteria, Mohr–Coulomb, Drucker–Prager, and modified Tresca, were suggested to describe yielding in polymeric solids. In this study, von Mises plasticity is used for the bulk material in the absence of voids, and macroscopic pressure dependency of yielding is introduced using Gurson yield function in the existence of voids for failure zone.

Several studies in the past have used optimization methods to determine GTN model parameters from experiments, either tensile or fracture, but this has been done exclusively for metals. The studies discussed above for polymers either do not involve any experiments or do not provide details of the determination process of GTN model parameters. Aoki et al. (1997) used Kalman filtering to obtain two nucleation parameters from two numerical tensile test experiments with a centered circular hole and side semicircular notches for an elastic–plastic material. Kalman filtering was also used by Corigliano et al. (2000) to obtain the GTN yield function coefficients from three-point bending experiments of steel single-edge-notched specimens. Mahnken (1999) used a Newton-like algorithm given by Bertsekas combined with the Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno method to obtain GTN parameters for an axisymmetric tensile test specimen made of steel. A gradient-based method using a Levenberg–Marquardt algorithm was employed to obtain initial, coalescence, and failure void volume fractions, nucleation parameters, power hardening coefficient, and initial yield values for a structural steel by Springmann and Kuna (2005, 2006). Broggiato et al. (2007) used the Nelder–Mead simplex method to obtain initial, coalescence, and failure void volume fractions, nucleation parameters using multisection optical data acquired from round-notched steel tensile specimens.

The goal of the present work is to explore the applicability of the GTN model to a photodegradable polyethylene carbon monoxide (ECO) copolymer and to obtain corresponding parameters for the GTN model through a robust optimization process that will couple experimental results from two different configurations as follows: uniaxial tension and edge-notched fracture. In the next section, we describe the details of the GTN model used here. In the section entitled ‘Experiments’, we summarize the experimental details of the work of Abanto-Bueno and Lambros (2004) and Abanto-Bueno (2004), on which this work is based. In the third section, the simulation details, and their link to experiments, are described. That is followed by a section that provides a critical discussion of the simulation results, and the last section shows the main conclusions of this effort.

sec.title: CONSTITUTIVE MODEL
sec.p: The work in this study was motivated by the experiments of Abanto-Bueno and Lambros (2004) and Patel (2005), which showed a ductile-to-brittle transition occurring with increasing amounts of ultraviolet (UV) irradiation of a 1% wt carbon monoxide polyethylene copolymer. For low amounts of irradiation (less than 10 h), shear yielding was the dominant failure mode, as is typical of ductile polymers. For higher amounts of irradiation, localized crazing became the dominant failure mechanism, similar to the case for brittle polymers, although globally significant nonlinearity was still maintained. Patel (2005) who has done microscale digital image correlation studies on the UV-irradiated ductile-to-brittle transition in ECO observed that both shear yielding and crazing produce nonlinearities, which may in fact look similar. But the mode of failure is different. In the brittle case, in a cracked ECO specimen loaded in tension, a cavity would first be formed ahead of the crack-tip; local stresses around this cavity then created new neighboring cavities that formed a craze precursor. This damage mechanism resembles the nucleation and growth of voids in a ductile metallic material, but is confined to locations directly ahead of the crack-tip rather than being distributed damage, as manifested in ductile metals. The craze formation reduces the material stress carrying capacity and eventually leads to failure. To simulate the damage formation in crazing ECO, the GTN model that predicts damage as a result of void nucleation, growth, and coalescence will be used here.

Reduction of stress carrying capacity can be expressed by a yield function Y for spherical voids with q1 = q2 = q3 = 1, f* = f by Gurson (1977). Later Tvergaard (1981) and Tvergaard and Needleman (1984) modified the yield function to the following form: (1) where σh = −σkk/3 is the macroscopic hydrostatic stress, σY is the tensile flow stress of the (matrix) material,

is the ultimate value of void volume fraction at which the stress carrying capacity vanishes (σeqv = 0, σh = 0), fc is the critical void volume fraction at which an accelerated void growth starts (also called initiation of void coalescence), and fF is the failure void volume fraction. The evolution of void volume fraction can be written both in terms of growth of existing voids and nucleation of new voids as follows: (3) where the superposed dots indicate the time derivative;

In this study, q3 is taken to be equal to

(which results in

). The initial value of void volume fraction f0 is 0 because cavities do not preexist in glassy polymers unlike in metals (Schirrer, 2001). A is taken to be constant to decrease the number of parameters to be optimized. B1 and B2 are set to zero in Equation (3) to omit the effect of stress rate on nucleation of voids. This is commonly employed, see, for example, Tvergaard (1981), Tvergaard and Needleman (1984), Sun et al. (1989), Narasimhan et al. (1992), Brocks et al. (1996), Kuna and Sun (1996), Skallerud and Zhang (1997), Xia and Cheng (1997), Gullerud et al. (2000), Al-Abbasi and Nemes (2008), and Benseddiq and Imad (2008) among others. Finally, the yield function and the evolution of void volume fraction can be written in the following form: (4) (5)
Failure occurs when f reaches fF (f* = fU).

sec.title: EXPERIMENTS
sec.p:
The experimental results used in this study are taken from the work done by Abanto-Bueno and Lambros (2004) and Abanto-Bueno (2004). In the interest of brevity, only a summary of the experimental details is given here. The reader is referred to the above references for more details. ECO becomes stiffer and more brittle when exposed to UV irradiation. Thin sheets of ECO (thickness 0.406 mm) 170 × 150 mm2 were artificially UV irradiated for different periods of time, 5, 42, and 130 h, and were cut into the uniaxial tensile and single-edge-notched tension (SENT) fracture test specimen geometries shown on the right in Figure 1. In this work, the 5, 42, and 130 h UV-irradiated ECO specimens will be labeled ECO 5, ECO 42, and ECO 130, respectively. The bulk material properties used for ECO in this work are tabulated in Table 1. Note that Poisson’s ratio and density do not exhibit a significant change with UV radiation. The specimen dimensions used in the experiments, which are the ones modeled here, are shown in Figure 1. The crosshead speed used in the experiments was 0.5 mm/min (approximately 0.01 mm/s). Table 1.
Calculated and measured mechanical properties of ECO.
Material property Virgin ECO ECO 5 ECO 42 ECO 130
Elastic modulus, E (MPa)a 178 223 277 332
Poisson’s ratio, νb 0.45 0.45 0.45 0.45
Initial yield stress, σ0 (MPa)a 1.18 1.28 1.37 1.45
Density, ρ (kg/m3)c 960 960 960 960
a
Calculated using experimental tension test results given by Abanto-Bueno (2004). b
Measured by Domininghaus (1993). c
Measured by Abanto-Bueno (2004).
Figure 1.
Geometry of (a) UV-irradiated ECO sheet; (b) tensile and (c) fracture specimens obtained from this sheet (Abanto-Bueno and Lambros, 2004).

sec.title: NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS PROCEDURE
sec.p: The GTN model is implemented using finite-elements (ABAQUS, 2009) and an inverse procedure to determine model parameters is used. Details of the numerical simulations and the GTN model parameter determination procedure from experiments are explained in the following subsections.

sec.title: Simulation of Uniaxial Tensile Response
sec.p:
The in-plane mesh used to model the uniaxial tension specimen is shown in Figure 2(a). The mesh has 1625 linear hexahedral elements of type C3D8R with 3528 nodes. Using symmetry, 1/8th of the entire specimen is modeled. To simulate progressive failure of multiple elements, ABAQUS/Explicit was used with a uniform mesh and an element size of 0.385 × 0.4 × 0.203 mm3. A displacement loading rate of 0.01 mm/s was used in the experiments, which would produce simulations of excessively long duration. The GTN model loading rate sensitivity was studied numerically, and rate dependency was not observed up to a loading of 10 mm/s. To reduce the computational time, a loading rate of 10 mm/s was used. This parametric rate sensitivity study investigates only the loading rate dependence of the GTN model, although in this study, only one set of experiments at a single loading rate was used. Bulk elastic and plastic material properties are taken from experimental results up to ultimate tensile strength, σUTS, where necking initiates. After σUTS, the bulk behavior stress value is kept constant at the ultimate value, as observed in the experiments until failure. Isotropic hardening is assumed for the bulk plastic flow. Figure 2.
Finite-element meshes for homogeneous ECO: (a) tensile test specimen and (b) SENT fracture test specimen.

Softening behavior is introduced numerically by applying the GTN model, but only to the bottom row elements in the mesh of Figure 2(a), thus forcing failure to occur at the line of symmetry of the sample. Thus, only the bottom row of elements is capable of softening in this configuration. This introduces a softening length scale in the problem (the height of the elements). It is known that such length scale dependence is present in the GTN model, and one question that arises is how to specify this length scale. As discussed in more detail later, in the present work, selection of this length scale is made from the experimentally observed failure region that is approximately 300–400 microns in half-height (Patel, 2005). Note that applying the GTN model to only a single row of elements where failure is expected, as is done here, is a common technique sometimes called the ‘computational cells’ method as proposed by Xia and Shih (1995a, b), and discussed by Brocks et al. (1996), Kuna and Sun (1996), Xia and Cheng (1997), Faleskog et al. (1998), Gao et al. (1998), Steglich and Brocks (1998), and Gullerud et al. (2000).

sec.title: Simulation of Single-Edge-Notched Tensile Tests
sec.p: For the SENT fracture specimen, 1/4th of the entire specimen was discretized, the dimensions of the model being 150 × 50 × 0.203 mm3. The GTN model parameters will depend on the mesh size, as stated above. Although the tensile testing experiments described above may not provide an inherent length scale for failure, in the fracture experiments, failure is produced by a single craze originating from the crack-tip (Abanto-Bueno, 2004). Thus, unlike the case of ductile metals where the failure region size may not be known, here, the craze has been experimentally measured to be around 300–400 microns in half-height, although this would depend to some extent on the level of irradiation. Therefore, in these simulations, softening GTN elements were again placed only directly ahead of the crack-tip and given a height of 400 microns (which was also kept the same for the tensile experiments described above). Thus, by combining both the fracture and tensile loading experiments in this work, we are able to specify the length scale over which softening will occur. Consequently, the graded in-plane mesh shown in Figure 2(b) was used to model the fracture experiments with the smallest element size chosen to be 0.4 × 0.4 × 0.203 mm3, which is close to half the size of a craze. The mesh has 2909 linear hexahedral elements of type C3D8R with 6288 nodes. The crack surface (0 mm < x < 30 mm and y = 0 mm) was kept traction free, and as before, a 10 mm/s displacement rate was applied at y = 50 mm. Material properties are the same as the tensile test’s specimen. Note that in this particular case, in order to check the validity of results, a simulation in which the GTN model was applied to all elements of the mesh was also conducted. The results of all simulations are discussed in detail in the Results and Discussion section.

sec.title: GTN Model Parameter Determination
sec.p: The bulk elastoplastic properties of the surrounding elements were taken directly from experiments as entire stress–strain curves, which were tabulated for the purposes of the numerical simulations. As mentioned above, the only modifications made to the experimental stress–strain curves was that, if needed in the simulations, they would not soften but rather would remain at a maximum value of σUTS if the strain evolved beyond that measured experimentally. Therefore, only the GTN parameters of the single row of ‘cells’ are unknown and need to be determined by minimizing a particular objective function (see below). Minimization is done using the Nelder–Mead simplex method, which is a direct search method that does not use numerical nor analytical gradients, which can overcome discontinuities near the optimal solution. In the case studied here, discontinuities may arise as a result of failure of the specimen. Each iteration of a simplex-based direct search method begins with a simplex, specified by its n + 1 vertices and the associated function values in an n-dimensional space. The reader is referred to the work of Lagarias et al. (1998) for details of the search algorithm.

To obtain optimum GTN model parameters, numerical results are correlated with experimental nominal stress–strain values (tension specimen) or load–displacement values (fracture specimen). Three different optimization calculations are performed as shown below for (i) the tensile specimen, (ii) the fracture specimen, and (iii) the tensile and fracture specimens together, for each different UV irradiation time, corresponding to varying amounts of ductility. Corresponding objective functions are of a least squares type and are given as follows: (6a) (6b) (6c) where
σ ¯
n
and σn(p) are experimentally and numerically evaluated normal stresses,
L ¯
m
and Lm(p) are experimental and numerical loads, and w is a weight factor (=1 × 106) to obtain a comparable order of magnitude between wϕ1(p) and wϕ2(p). p is defined as follows with five parameters: (7) where q1, q2, and q3 are GTN yield function coefficients given in Equation (1) and q3 =
q 3
= q 1 2
; fc and fF are critical and failure void volume fractions given in Equation (2); A is the constant coefficient in Equation (3) for the strain-controlled void nucleation rate term.

From the numerical simulations of the tensile specimen, output quantities were collected at every 1.25 × 10−3 strain intervals up to a total of 0.125 strain for each of the different irradiation time experiments ECO 5, ECO 42, and ECO 130. This yields a total number for N (the total number of points in Equations 6a and 6c) of 100. For the fracture specimen, simulation data are collected at every 0.01 mm applied displacement intervals up to 5.9, 4.9, and 4.1 mm for ECO 5, ECO 42, and ECO 130, respectively. As a result, M is 590, 490, and 410 in Equations 6b and 6c for ECO 5, ECO 42, and ECO 130.

sec.title: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p:
The results of the minimization process, along with the experimentally measured boundary stress versus strain and load versus load line displacement, are shown for ECO 5 in Figure 3(a) and (b), respectively. Figure 3(a) shows the nominal stress–strain relation measured during the uniaxial tension experiment along with the numerically predicted response using the optimized GTN properties with Equation (6a) as a minimization function, that is, minimizing solely based on this experimental stress–strain curve (square symbols). In addition to this, it is possible to make a combined minimization using both the tensile and the fracture results (Figure 3(a) and (b)) through Equation (6c). In this case, somewhat different GTN coefficients are obtained, as is seen in Table 2. Softening elements are placed: (i) everywhere (full GTN) and (ii) at the bottom row only (computational cells method – row GTN). For combined function minimization (Equation 6c), two cases have been considered as follows: (a) full GTN for SENT specimen and row GTN for tension specimen are used; (b) row GTN for both SENT and tension specimens is used. Both cases are plotted in Figure 3(a). It is clear from Figure 3(a) that all three cases produce excellent agreement with the experimental results and are virtually indistinguishable from each other. This implies that using data from a single tension test to extract GTN failure parameters does not allow unique identification of these parameters but rather a wide range of values can fit the single tension test data equally well. Table 2.
Optimized GTN model parameters and objective function values for ECO 5 simulations.
Case Optimized GTN model parameters Objective function values
q1 q2 fc fF A ϕ1 ϕ2 ϕ3
ϕ1 minimization 3.044 1.073 0.152 0.246 0.1273 0.0539 N/A N/A
ϕ2 minimization (row GTN) 3.050 0.539 0.224 0.325 0.1586 348 678,167 348,678,167
ϕ2 minimization (full GTN) 3.047 0.547 0.218 0.328 0.1640 254 592,887 254,592,887
ϕ3 minimization (row GTN) 3.136 0.660 0.176 0.307 0.1649 0.0836 2,229,964 2,313,564
ϕ3 minimization (full GTN) 3.136 0.660 0.178 0.318 0.1649 0.0853 1,603,151 1,688,451
ϕi are given in Equations (6a)–(6c).
Figure 3.
Experimental and numerical responses of (a) tensile test specimen, and (b) SENT fracture test specimen for ECO 5, where ϕi are given in Equations (6a)–(6c).

Figure 3(b) shows results for the applied load versus load line displacement for the ECO 5 case. If the tension test results are fitted on their own, Equation (6a), and the resulting properties are used to predict the fracture response, then the predicted results (square symbol) deviate considerably from the experimental results. If the fracture load–displacement curve is used on its own, that is, Equation (6b) is minimized, then we obtain the curves in Figure 3(b) shown as triangles (full GTN model for entire mesh) and pluses (single row GTN elements). As is seen, this predicted response is an improvement over the results obtained by solely optimizing stress–strain, but it overpredicts the failure load considerably. Note, however, that there is little difference between the full GTN model and the computational cells model. This was seen in all cases simulated, so from now on, only the computational cells model results will be shown. However, when comparing the model prediction for a uniaxial response based on the ϕ2 minimization only, the results, shown as plus symbols (single row GTN elements) and triangle symbols (full GTN model for entire mesh) in Figure 3(a), are poor compared to the previous ones. Therefore, we cannot obtain a consistent set of optimized properties by minimizing separately either the uniaxial response or the SENT fracture experimental data.

In an attempt to improve the fit quality, we next minimize the function in Equation (6c), which performs a simultaneous minimization of the uniaxial and fracture test data. The results for the computational cells model (circle symbols) and the full model (cross symbols) are also plotted in Figure 3(b). The results agree quite well with the previous minimization up to about peak load, which is now better estimated, although the maximum displacement is underestimated when using both tension and fracture data in the minimization process. Comparing Figure 3(a) and (b) clearly shows that the fracture experiment is much more sensitive to the model parameters, particularly after peak load, than the uniaxial response, and it is especially difficult to accurately predict both peak load and peak displacement. However, the combined minimization does produce excellent agreement for the uniaxial response and reasonable agreement for the fracture response, and is therefore considered representative of the material.

The experiments corresponding to ECO 42 and ECO 130 essentially represent different materials because nominally higher UV irradiation hours would further embrittle the polymer. So the minimization process was repeated separately for each one, and the results are presented in Figures 4 and 5 for ECO 42 and 130, respectively. Here, only the computational cells method results are shown and only for the case of either the individual or the combined minimizations. Similar results are seen, with the combined minimization generally able to better predict peak load, but less so peak displacement. Generally, as irradiation time increases, parameters fc and fF decrease indicating an embrittlement of the material, as expected. However, in the most brittle case, 130 h of irradiation, the fit is also the worst, which perhaps is also expected because we are attempting to model an increasingly brittle material with what is inherently a ductile failure model. Although the goal of this article was not to obtain a specific variation of the GTN parameters with irradiation time, there appears to be a reasonable trend in the results. Figure 4.
Experimental and numerical responses of (a) tensile test specimen, and (b) SENT fracture test specimen for ECO 42, where ϕi are given in Equations (6a)–(6c). Figure 5.
Experimental and numerical responses of (a) tensile test specimen, and (b) SENT fracture test specimen for ECO 130, where ϕi are given in Equations (6a)–(6c).

In Tables 2–4, GTN model parameters q1, q2, fc, fF, and A that are obtained for 5, 42, and 130 h UV-irradiated ECO are tabulated. ϕ1, ϕ2, and ϕ3 in these tables correspond to optimization considering tensile, fracture, and combined tensile and fracture tests. Table 3.

ϕ3 minimization (full GTN) 3.128 0.735 0.158 0.278 0.1684 0.0817 1,103,666 1,185,366

Equivalent stress contour plots for the ECO 42 SENT fracture specimen near the initial crack-tip are shown in Figure 6(a)–(d) for different loading values using GTN model parameters obtained by minimizing ϕ3. Similarly, equivalent plastic strain contour plots are shown in Figure 7(a)–(d). Both sets of contour plots begin from a fully elastic deformation loading state (at 0.05 mm applied displacement) and end at total failure of the first element ahead of the initial crack-tip (at 2.67 mm applied displacement). Contour levels are the same for each stress plot but not for plastic strain plots. Note that the elements where failure initiates deform significantly because they soften and lose their stress-carrying capacity eventually. Therefore, the second contour level for the plastic strain plots is kept constant at 0.05 to clearly visualize the extent of plasticity developing above the failure zone directly ahead of the crack in Figure 7(c)–(d). Stress is clearly concentrated around the ‘apparent’ crack-tip. In Figure 6(a)–(b), for early loads, while deformation is still mainly elastic, the apparent crack-tip is located at the original crack-tip position. As the elements at the interface accumulate plastic strain (Figure 7(c)), they soften considerably, thus causing the apparent crack-tip to move forward because that is where the stress-carrying capacity of the material now resides, and consequently, where stress is concentrated. This is reminiscent of the formation and growth of a craze ahead of a crack-tip in a polymeric material. This happens before total failure of the first element, which has not reached fF yet. It is the severe softening that essentially causes the formation of this craze. A process such as this can also be modeled by the concept of a cohesive zone model (CZM), which clearly should be relatable to the GTN model used in this study. In fact, cohesive strength and energy have been predicted using the GTN model to simulate failure and relating the results to a CZM (Siegmund and Brocks, 1999; Anvari et al., 2007). It is the beyond the scope of this effort to make such a relation. Figures 6–7(d) show the equivalent stress and plastic strain contour plots at the instant of total failure of the first element ahead of the initial crack-tip. Softening is much more severe in this case, so the apparent crack-tip moves forward excessively and plastic strain spreads to a large region of the entire sample either side of the craze. Figure 6.
Evolution of equivalent stress near the crack-tip for ECO 42 SENT fracture specimen at load line displacements of (a) 0.05 mm, (b) 0.9 mm, (c) 1.8 mm, and (d) 2.67 mm using GTN model parameters obtained by minimizing ϕ3. Figure 7.
Evolution of equivalent plastic strain near the crack-tip for ECO 42 SENT fracture specimen at load line displacements of (a) 0.05 mm, (b) 0.9 mm, (c) 1.8 mm, and (d) 2.67 mm using GTN model parameters obtained by minimizing ϕ3.

To compare the three different UV irradiation times, equivalent stress and equivalent plastic strain contour plots are shown in Figure 8 for ECO 5, ECO 42, and ECO 130 SENT fracture specimens at a constant applied load line displacement of 2 mm at which level in all three cases, significant damage has accumulated ahead of the crack-tip. GTN model parameters obtained by minimizing the combined ϕ3 have been used. The apparent crack-tip moves further and the magnitude of stresses increases as irradiation time increases, which is a consequence of the material becoming not only more brittle (failure stain decreasing) but also stiffer (stress increases). Figure 8.
Equivalent stress and equivalent plastic strain contour plots for ECO 5, ECO 42, and ECO 130 SENT fracture specimens before the total failure of first element ahead the initial crack-tip where load line displacement is 2 mm.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this work, the GTN model was used to simulate failure of a UV-irradiated ECO copolymer. The GTN model parameters for different UV irradiation times were obtained through using experimental tensile and/or fracture results obtained from Abanto-Bueno and Lambros (2004) and Abanto-Bueno (2004). The characteristic length scale of application of the GTN model was taken to correspond to the craze size of the polymer, producing an in-plane mesh size of minimum element size 0.4 × 0.4 mm2, which is close to half the size of a craze. Numerical results of tensile test specimens were in good agreement with experimental ones. Results obtained using different objective functions overlapped and did not exhibit a significant difference except at perhaps near the failure point (Figures 3–5(a)). However, this was not the case for the fracture experiments, although the results of different minimizations did agree well up to a certain load point. A scheme where both the uniaxial tension and the SENT fracture data were simultaneously used in the GTN parameter determination was proposed. In the combined cases, numerical results of ultimate load overshoot the experimental ones by approximately 10%, and the corresponding displacements are predicted well, although with less accuracy. In general, the shapes of the response curves are also similar to the experimental ones for fracture specimens (Figures 3–5(b)).

Regarding the specific GTN parameters obtained, as the UV irradiation time is increased, fc and fF values generally decrease. This is reasonable because the increase in brittleness of ECO is consistent with increasing UV irradiation time. As was mentioned in the introduction, in the literature, the GTN model has been widely used to study failure of metals, for example, steel, aluminum, and copper (Tvergaard, 1981; Tvergaard and Needleman, 1984; Sun et al., 1989; Narasimhan et al., 1992; Brocks et al., 1996; Kuna and Sun, 1996; Skallerud and Zhang, 1997; Xia and Cheng, 1997; Faleskog et al., 1998; Pardoen et al., 1998; Steglich and Brocks, 1998; Gullerud et al., 2000; Benseddiq and Imad, 2008). From such a wide variety of studies, the GTN model parameters for metals can be seen to lie in the ranges: (8)
In the current study, these parameters are obtained as follows: (9)

The difference in q1 between the polymer and metals is striking, although for the remaining values this is less so. A higher value for q1 has been calculated than metals. This indicates that ECO is more sensitive to stress triaxiality. A comparable q1 value of 2.6 was obtained from true stress–strain and volume variation data for a rubber-toughened PMMA tensile specimen by Zaïri et al. (2005) who used a viscoplastic–damage constitutive model.

In conclusion, we have shown that the GTN model is promising for damage simulations of polymeric materials. Different constitutive models for bulk material and different optimization methods can be used to improve numerical results.

fn.p: Figures 6–8 appear in color online: http://ijd.sagepub.com
